metadata.titel_preek: A Kind Answer And A Sad Question

primair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: Jesus encounters ten lepers who seek mercy; He heals them, but only one returns to offer the 'Object' of the story: the right worship of God through gratitude.

subject.identificatie: Jesus (as the Divine Actor) and the Samaritan (as the responding Subject).
tekstueel_bewijs: The kind answer and the sad question in this passage both came from the lips and heart of Jesus.
He said to them, 'Go show yourselves unto the priests.'

object.identificatie: Wholeness/Salvation (beyond mere physical healing) and the Glorification of God.
tekstueel_bewijs: Your faith has made you whole.
The right worship of God is to return glorifying God with a loud voice.

zender.identificatie: God the Father / The Divine Will.
tekstueel_bewijs: God stands in need of nothing else... The earth is his.

ontvanger.identificatie: The Ten Lepers (initially), the Samaritan (fully), and the Hearer.
tekstueel_bewijs: He is a Sun ever shining... a God ever blessing.
ontvanger.positie_hoorder: The hearer is invited to identify with the 'nine' who are ungrateful, but urged to become the 'one' who returns.

tekstueel_bewijs: as they walked by faith, they were healed
helped by the church in the name of the Lord
helper.rol_van_god: God is the primary Subject/Source, not merely a tool.
helper.rol_van_geest: Implicit as the power behind the 'holy power' of healing.

tekstueel_bewijs: the winter of ingratitude and knew the chill of being forsaken
they took the gift; they forgot the Giver
tegenstander.toelichting_ernst: Ingratitude is presented not just as a manners issue, but as a failure to enter into 'wholeness' and the Lamb's book of life.

secundair_narratief_programma.beschrijving: The ethical response of the believer to God's prior grace (The 'Return').
secundair_narratief_programma.subject: The Hearer/Believer.
secundair_narratief_programma.toelichting_verhouding: The healing (Primary) precedes the gratitude (Secondary). The sermon warns against 'short-circuiting' the program by receiving the gift without the Giver.

voorbeelden_god_subject: He in our dying saves us
The Lord is constantly giving us kind answers
voorbeelden_mens_subject: You walked away without ever a backward glance

voorbeelden: those who receive much... ought to respond greatly
he wished for his friends... that they might know his gladness
Luke is careful to point that out
he in our weakness strengthens us
he in our dying saves us

modale_analyse.modale_interpretatie: The sermon emphasizes God's 'ability' to save and heal (Pouvoir) over the human 'obligation' (Devoir), though it laments the failure of the human 'will' (Vouloir) to thank Him.

primaire_tegenstelling.niet_s2: Physical Cleansing (The Gift without the Giver)

semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.beweging_in_preek: From S2 (Leprosy) to ~S2 (Physical healing) to S1 (Wholeness/Praise), while warning against getting stuck at ~S2.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.theologische_resolutie: Resolution is found in the 'Return' to Jesus, where the physical gift is integrated into a spiritual relationship.
semiotisch_vierkant_analyse.ernst_van_s2: High; leprosy is described as a stigma and exclusion from community/God.

diagnostische_evaluatie.classificatie_toelichting: While the sermon contains strong calls to action (gratitude), it grounds everything in the prior, miraculous, and unmerited 'kind answer' of Jesus. God remains the primary actor in the verbs of salvation.

indicatoren_moralisme.tekstueel_bewijs: if each of us decided to play fair with God

indicatoren_genade.indicator: God as the initiator of the search
indicatoren_genade.tekstueel_bewijs: him who came a long journey looking for us

exemplarisme_check.beschrijving: The Samaritan is used as a model of 'right worship'.
exemplarisme_check.alternatieve_lezing: The sermon avoids pure moralism by noting that the Samaritan's return was a response to a 'holy power' already at work.

identificatie_patroon.effect_op_hoorder: Conviction of ingratitude followed by an invitation to joy.
identificatie_patroon.theologische_implicatie: Salvation is a gift that demands a total life-response (glorification).

narratieve_coherentie.coherentie_beschrijving: The transition from the biblical story to the contemporary application (physical health, national history) is seamless.
spanning_punten: The tension between 'playing fair with God' (merit-adjacent) and 'God stands in need of nothing' (pure grace).

soteriologie.tekstueel_bewijs: Your faith has made you whole... registered in the divine memory.

pneumatologie.competentie_schenking: The sermon focuses more on the Christological 'Kind Answer' than the internal work of the Spirit.

hamartologie.ernst_diagnose: Moderate to High; sin is 'defilement' and 'ingratitude'.

aanbevelingen.actantiele_audit_samenvatting: The narrative engine is driven by Jesus's movement toward the marginalized. The 'Subject' of the healing is clearly Christ.

identificatie_herstel.problematische_identificatie: The hearer might feel they must 'produce' gratitude to be 'whole'.
identificatie_herstel.voorgestelde_identificatie: The hearer as the 'Receiver' of the 'Sun ever shining'.
identificatie_herstel.strategie: Emphasize that the 'return' is also a gift of the Spirit's prompting.

modale_balans.huidige_onbalans: Slightly high on Devoir (ought) in the middle section.
modale_balans.voorgestelde_balans: Increase Pouvoir (God's power to enable gratitude).
modale_balans.concrete_suggestie: Frame the 'return' as a fruit of the miracle rather than a payment for it.

tegenstander_intensivering.huidige_status: The 'Opponent' of ingratitude is well-developed as a 'chill' and 'winter'.

narratieve_hierarchie_herstel.voorgestelde_structuur: The hierarchy is correct: Healing (Grace) -> Return (Response).

aanbevelingen.slotopmerking: A masterful example of theocentric preaching that uses human experience to highlight divine initiative.

comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_retorische_analyse: A rhetorical analysis would focus on the 'sad/kind' pathos; Greimas reveals the underlying transfer of 'Wholeness' as the Object.
comparatieve_analyse.verschil_met_exegese: Exegesis explains the Samaritan/Jew divide; semiotics shows how this divide functions as an 'Opponent' overcome by the 'Subject' (Jesus).
comparatieve_analyse.unieke_inzichten_greimas: Reveals that the 'Nine' are actantially 'failed receivers' who accepted the Object but rejected the Sender.

appendices.notities: The sermon successfully avoids the 'Be like the Samaritan' trap by focusing on the 'Kindness of Jesus' as the source of the Samaritan's ability to return.
